ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Marigold-like
Cu
x ( x = 1.81 , 2 )
S
$\mbox{Cu}_{x (x=1.81, 2)}\mbox{S}$ nanocrystals: controllable synthesis, field emission, and photocatalytic properties

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Polar Materials and Devices (Ministry of Education of China), Department of Electronic Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Cubic marigold-like Cu2S nanostructures were synthesized from a facile hydrothermal process without using any additives or surfactants. After thermal annealed at different condition, monoclinic Cu2S and tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures were obtained for the first time, maintaining the marigold-like morphology undestroyed. Field emission (FE) properties of these three types of nanostructures were investigated for the first time. The results indicated that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures had excellent field emission performance with turn-on field of
âˆ¼ 2.1
V/Î¼m
and threshold field of
âˆ¼ 5.2
V/Î¼m
. Moreover, their photocatalytic properties of the three nanostructures were also investigated by photodegradating methylene blue (MB). The results showed that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures may be a competitive material in both field emission and photocatalytic applications.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Chalcogenide semiconductor nanomaterials, such as ZnS, CdS, and PbS, have attracted increasing attention from the scientific community due to their specific chemical and physical properties, which differ greatly from those of bulk counterparts [1]. Among them, copper sulfide (
Cu
x ( x = 1 â€“ 2 )
S
$\mbox{Cu}_{x (x=1\scriptsize{\mbox{--}}2)}\mbox{S}$ ) nanocrystals have become an interesting research area because of their complex structures and varied stoichiometric compositions and phases [2]. Cu x S is known to have at least nine phases [3â€“5], including at least five stable phases at room temperature, ranging from Cu2S on the copper-rich side to CuS on the copper-poor side [6]. All the stable copper-rich compounds of Cu x S are p-type semiconductor because of the copper vacancies within the lattice [7, 8], such as Cu2S (chalcocite) [9], Cu1.94S (djurleite) [10], and Cu1.8S (digenite) [11, 12]. As to the Cu2S (chalcocite), it exhibits a phase transition from
Î³
$\gamma$ -Cu2S (monoclinic low-chalcocite) to
Î²
$\beta$ -Cu2S (hexagonal high-chalcocite) at
101.5
âˆ˜
C
$101.5~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ [13] in the nanowire and
103.5
âˆ˜
C
$103.5~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ in the bulk [14] on heating, respectively. Being a p-type semiconductor with band gaps around 1.2â€“2.74Â eV [4, 6, 15], Cu x S is a promising candidate for photovoltaics, field emission devices, lithium-ion batteries, and photocatalysts. Due to the attractive applications of Cu x S, several chemical and physical techniques have been investigated to prepare Cu x S nanostructures with different phases, which include solution-phase reactions, hydrothermal methods, ultrasonic and microwave irradiation, photochemical deposition, template-assisted methods, spray pyrolysis, chemical vapor deposition, activated reactive evaporation, and so on [16â€“18]. Nowadays, many efforts have been devoted to the shape controlled fabrication of various Cu x S nanocrystals, and a lot of morphologies of Cu x S have been synthesized such as nanowires, nanorods, nanotubes, nanoflakes, nanoflowers, hollow microspheres [19â€“23], etc.

Despite these attractive features and many efforts on the application of Cu x S, there have been few reports on the field emission (FE) properties of Cu x S nanostructures. Chen etÂ al. [24] first reported the electron emission performance of Cu2S nanowires. These straight crystalline Cu2S nanowire arrays were synthesized by using a gasâ€“solid reaction at room temperature. In this work, using a mild, convenient, and nontoxic hydrothermal method, phase-pure cubic Cu2S crystals with marigold-like morphology were successfully synthesized. Then, Cu2S crystals were transferred from cubic to monoclinic (Cu2S) and tetragonal (Cu1.81S) after a heat treatment at different ambience conditions. Field emission (FE) investigation of these three types of nanostructures indicated that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures had the best field emission performance with turn-on field of
âˆ¼ 2.1
V/Î¼m
and threshold field of
âˆ¼ 5.2
V/Î¼m
. Moreover, their photocatalytic properties were also investigated by photodegradating methylene blue (MB), exhibiting the highest photocatalytic efficiency for Cu1.81S. These results showed that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures are competitive material in both field emission and photocatalytic applications.

Section2.Heading: Synthesis of Cu2S nanoflowers
Section2.Para:
Cu2S nanoflowers were synthesized by one-step hydrothermal procedure without using any additives or surfactants. All the chemical reagents used in this experiment were analytical grade and used without further purification. In a typical procedure, 1Â g of CuCl
â‹…
2
$_{2}\cdot$ 2H2O powder and 0.8Â g of thiourea powder were added into 80Â mL ethanol to form yellowâ€“green slurry. The slurry was stirred for 30Â min and then transferred into a 100Â mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at
160
âˆ˜
C
$160~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ for 6 h and then air-cooled to room temperature. The resulting dark precipitates (cubic chalcocite Cu2S) were collected and washed with distilled water and ethanol several times and then dried at
50
âˆ˜
C
$50~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ under vacuum for 10Â h. At last, monoclinic chalcocite Cu2S and tetragonal digenite Cu1.81S powders were obtained by heating Cu2S (cubic chalcocite) at
650
âˆ˜
C
$650~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ in a high purity (99.999Â %) argon atmosphere and a mixed atmosphere of high purity argon and high-purity (99.99Â %) oxygen (flow ratio 99:1) for 3 h, respectively. The total pressures in the heating process were both kept at 1.05 atm. After that, powders obtained under mixed atmosphere were ultrasonicated for 5Â min and filtered to remove the small quantity of oxide. The resulting dark precipitates were collected and washed with distilled water and ethanol several times and then dried at
50
âˆ˜
C
$50~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ under vacuum for 10Â h.

Section2.Heading: Sample characterization
Section2.Para:
The crystal morphology and structure of the resulting products were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL-JSM-6700F) at an accelerating voltage of 20Â kV, X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer) with Cuâ€‰
K Î±
$K_{\alpha}$ radiation (
Î» = 1.5418
Ã…
) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL-JEM-2100) at an accelerating voltage of 200Â kV. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried out on a RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system with Mgâ€‰
K Î±
${K}_{\alpha}$ radiation (
h Î½ = 1253.6
eV
$h \nu=1253.6~\mbox{eV}$ ). Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, DSC-60, Shimadzu) experiments were performed in nitrogen flow in the temperature from
40
âˆ˜
C
$40~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ to
150
âˆ˜
C
$150~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ with a heating rate of
5
âˆ˜
C/min
$5~^{\circ}\mbox{C/min}$ . The Brunauerâ€“Emmettâ€“Teller (BET) surface area (
S BET
$S_{\mathrm{BET}}$ ) of the products was analyzed in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus.

Section2.Heading: Field-emission measurement
Section2.Para:
For field emission investigation, the synthesized samples of Cu2S (cubic chalcocite), Cu2S (monoclinic chalcocite), and Cu1.81S (tetragonal digenite) were painted on the silicon substrates by a screen-printing method, respectively. The silicon substrate with nanomaterial (as a cathode) was separated from an indium tin oxide (ITO)/glass anode by two Teflon spacers with a thickness of
200
Î¼m
. Field emission properties were measured with a high vacuum level of about
2 Ã—
10
âˆ’ 5
Pa
$2\times10^{-5}~\mathrm{Pa}$ at room temperature using transparent anode imaging technique. The measured emission area was
1 Ã— 1
cm 2
$1\times 1~\mathrm{cm}^{2}$ . In the measurement, the turn-on field is determined as the field produces a current density of
1
Î¼A/cm 2
, and the threshold field is the field produces a current density of 0.1Â mA/cm2.

Section2.Heading: Photocatalytic measurements
Section2.Para:
Methylene blue (MB), a common cationic dye or contaminant in industrial wastewater, was chosen to examine the samplesâ€™ photodegradation for its strong absorption in the visible region and excellent skeletal stability under various pH conditions [2]. The evaluation of photocatalytic activity of the as-prepared samples was performed at room temperature. The procedure was as follows: the as-synthesized product yielded by one experiment was dispersed into 100Â mL MB solution (
10
mg L
âˆ’ 1
$10~\mbox{mg L}^{-1}$ ). Before irradiation, the mixed solution was stirred in dark for 15Â min to obtain a good dispersion and stabilize the adsorption/desorption equilibrium between the organic molecules and the catalyst surface. The solution was irradiated by an 18Â W daylight lamp (25Â cm above the reactor). The MB concentration was analyzed by a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UNICO 2802) every 15Â min during the total irradiation time of 60Â min for these three samples, respectively. ToÂ minimize the heat effect, the reactor was fixed on a big glass container that was filled with flowing water.

Section2.Heading: Structure and morphology
Section2.Para:
FigureÂ 1(a) shows the typical XRD pattern of Cu2S nanostructures obtained (red line). All the diffraction peaks are indexed to a cubic chalcocite Cu2S phase with lattice constants of
a = b = c = 0.5628
nm
$a= b = c = 0.5628~\mbox{nm}$ (JCPDS Card No. 84-1770). The observed peaks could be assigned to diffraction from the plane of (111), (200), (220), and (311). No peaks of any other phases or impurities were detected, showing that the products are mainly composed of cubic Cu2S. FigureÂ 1(b) is the representative XRD pattern of the Cu2S samples annealed at a high-purity argon atmosphere (green line). All the peaks are indexed to the monoclinic chalcocite Cu2S phase with lattice constants of
a = 1.524
nm
$a = 1.524~\mbox{nm}$ ,
b = 1.188
nm
$b = 1.188~\mbox{nm}$ , and
c = 1.349
nm
$c = 1.349~\mbox{nm}$ (JCPDS 83-1462), and there is no characteristic peak of other impurities. Furthermore, if the heat treatment is performed under an
O 2
$\mathrm{O}_{2}$ /Ar mixture atmosphere, tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoparticles were obtained. FigureÂ 1(c) is the corresponding XRD patterns (in blue) for the Cu1.81S sample after purification. It exhibited the characteristic peaks for the tetragonal digenite structure of Cu1.81S with lattice constants of
a = b = 0.7558
nm
$a =b = 0.7558~\mbox{nm}$ and
c = 1.834
nm
$c = 1.834~\mbox{nm}$ (JCPDS 41-0959). No peaks of CuO, Cu2O, or other impurities were detected. The three different Cu x S crystal structures are shown as insets of Figs.Â 1(a)â€“(c), respectively. The structure of tetragonal Cu1.81S nanocrystals is similar to the cubic chalcocite Cu2S, while only nearly
9 / 10
$9/10$ of the Cu sites are occupied [25]. The deviation of stoichiometric ratio can be explained by the copper deficiencies and copper vacancies formation in the heat-treatment process. Similar phenomena were also reported in previous reports [26, 27], in which Cu1.96S, Cu1.9S, and Cu1.8S can be obtained by controlled oxidation of Cu2S. XPS analyses can also establish the chemical composition and mole ratio of Cu1.81S nanocrystals. In Fig.Â 2(a), only two sharp peaks are observed. The binding energies of the observed photoelectron peaks of Cu

$2p_{1/2}$ to Cu1.81S are 932.2Â eV and 952.2Â eV, which are attributed toÂ Cu1+. In Fig.Â 2(b), the binding energy of SÂ
2 p
$2p$ is 161.1Â eV, which is attributed toÂ
S
2 âˆ’
$\mathrm{S}^{2 -}$ . The mole ratio of Cu:S is 1.84:1, which is very close to 1.81:1. This is in agreement with the XRD results described above.

The initial morphology of the as-prepared cubic Cu2S nanostructure was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). FiguresÂ 3(a)â€“(b) show the general SEM images at different magnifications. FigureÂ 3(a) gives the low-magnification SEM image of the cubic Cu2S nanostructures. The SEM observation shows that the as-obtained Cu2S (cubic) is made up of uniformly sized particles, which display marigold-like morphology (called nanoflowers here) with an average diameter of 1.5 to
2
Î¼m
. As shown in the middle-magnification SEM image (Fig.Â 3(b)), the surface morphology of the nanoflowers possess a nanosheet-assembled marigold-like pattern. These structures with sharp edge are very effective to improve the field emission properties. A high-magnification SEM image shown in the inset of Fig.Â 3(b) reveals that these nanosheets have a thickness of about 20Â nm. Moreover, they are aligned to the spherical surface, pointing toward a common inner center. After heat treatment under different ambience, monoclinic Cu2S and tetragonal Cu1.81S were obtained, and morphologies of them are very similar to the initial cubic Cu2S, and we do not list them here.
Fig.Â 3
(a) Low-magnification SEM image for the cubic Cu2S nanoflowers synthesized at
160
âˆ˜
C
$160~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ . (b)Â Medium-magnification SEM image of cubic Cu2S nanoflowers. The inset is the high-magnification SEM image of a single nanoflower. (c)Â TEM image of cubic Cu2S samples. (d)Â High-resolution TEM image for a selected area marked within a red rectangle from a nanosheet (Fig.Â 3(c)). Lower inset is an HRTEM image corresponding to a selected area marked within a white rectangle. Upper inset is the corresponding SAED pattern

In addition, the TEM image is shown in Fig.Â 3(c), indicating that the Cu2S (cubic) nanoflowers were constructed by intersectional nanosheets. The high-resolution TEM image and the corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern are shown in Fig.Â 3(d), indicating that the nanoflower is a single crystal, and the lattice spacing is 0.556Â nm, corresponding to d-spacing of the (100) plane of Cu2S nanosheets.

FigureÂ 4 shows a set of
N 2
$\mathrm{N}_{2}$ adsorption/desorption isotherms, which could be identified as characteristic of mesoporous materials as-obtained. Three distinct hysteresis loops are identified, indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure, which leads to a Brunauerâ€“Emmettâ€“Teller (BET) surface area of
21.4
m 2
/g
$21.4~\mathrm{m}^{2}\mbox{/g}$ for cubic Cu2S nanoflowers,
20.2
m 2
/g
$20.2~\mathrm{m}^{2}\mbox{/g}$ for monoclinic Cu2S nanoflowers, and
23.6
m 2
/g
$23.6 \mathrm{m}^{2}\mbox{/g}$ for tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers. The similar results of specific surface area indicate that the surface morphologies of the latter two samples do not change noteworthily after anneal, which is well consistent with the SEM results.

The transition characteristics of different Cu x S samples were also investigated by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement, and the corresponding curves are shown in Fig.Â 5. Interestingly, reversible phase transition of monoclinic Cu2S (green line) and Cu1.81S (blue line) are found from the DSC investigation. During the heating process, the transition occurs at
95.7
âˆ˜
C
$95.7~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ and
99.3
âˆ˜
C
$99.3~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ (endothermic peak), corresponding to monoclinic Cu2S (green line) and tetragonal Cu1.81S (blue line), respectively. No phase transition occurs for cubic Cu2S (red line). For monoclinic Cu2S and tetragonal Cu1.81S [15], the endothermic phenomenon is related to the phase transition from low-chalcocite to high-chalcocite and low-digenite to high-digenite respectively. Instead, when these samples are cooled from
150
âˆ˜
C
$150~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ to
40
âˆ˜
C
$40~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ , the phase transition occurs at
77.2
âˆ˜
C
$77.2~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ (exothermic peak) for monoclinic Cu2S and
85.7
âˆ˜
C
$85.7~^{\circ}\mbox{C}$ for tetragonal Cu1.81S, respectively. No phase transition occurs for cubic Cu2S either. The significantly lowered phase transition temperature of monoclinic Cu2S and tetragonal Cu1.81S shows a heating-cooling hysteresis, which may be due to the kinetic effect that slows down the transition from a high-entropy phase to a low-entropy phase [13]. The phase transition temperature of the Cu x S nanoflowers appears to be a little shift comparing with the bulk and nanowire, which can be attributed to the size reduction in the nanometer regime [28].

5

Section2.Heading: Field emission studies
Section2.Para:
Field emission properties of the as-prepared samples were measured by the method described in the experimental section. Although the field emission properties of Cu2S nanowires have already been studied by other groups [24, 29], the field emission properties of marigold-like morphology of Cu x S nanocrystals have not been researched yet. Herein, three types of nanostructures of monoclinic Cu2S, cubic Cu2S, and tetragonal Cu1.81S were measured at room temperature for the first time. Generally, field emission mainly depends on the emitter geometry [30, 31]. These Cu x S nanostructures are all constructed by nanosheets with a thickness of about 20Â nm. Therefore, it is reasonable that electrons can be emitted easily from these nanosheets. Plots of FE current density versus applied field (
J
$J$ â€“
E
$E$ ) are shown in Fig.Â 6(a). It is visible that the emission current density
J
$J$ exponentially increases with the increase of the applied fieldÂ
E
$E$ . The tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures have the lowest turn-on field of
2.1
V/Î¼m
and the lowest threshold field of
5.2
V/Î¼m
. Meanwhile, the turn-on fields and threshold fields for monoclinic Cu2S as well as cubic Cu2S nanostructures are
4.1
V/Î¼m
and
7.6
V/Î¼m
,
5.6
V/Î¼m
, and
8.9
V/Î¼m
as shown in Fig.Â 6(a), respectively. It is clear that the field emission property for the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures is the best among those of the other two samples.
Fig.Â 6
(a) The dependence of the FE current density
J
$J$ on the applied electric field strength
E
$E$ of cubic Cu2S nanoflowers (red curve), monoclinic Cu2S nanoflowers (green curve), and tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers (blue curve), respectively. The inset is the schematic illustration for FE measurement. (b)Â The corresponding Fowlerâ€“Nordheim relation of

E 2
)
$\ln(J/E^{2})$ â€“

$1/E$ plots for these three types of samples. (c)Â Emission stability for these three types of samples with original emission current density of
2
mA/cm 2
$2~\mbox{mA/cm}^{2}$

The corresponding Fowlerâ€“Nordheim (Fâ€“N) plots are shown in Fig.Â 6(b). The Fâ€“N plots exhibit nonlinear characteristics that are also observed during the field emission experiments of SmB6 nanowires, Cu2S nanowires, and carbon nanotube films [29, 32]. Each plot can be divided into three regions. Regions 1 and 3 can be fitted by two straight lines with different slopes, and it can be found that the slopes are larger at high-field regions than those at low-field regions. Region 2 is a nonlinear transition state between regions 1 andÂ 3. The exact mechanism of the nonlinear characteristics is not clear yet. It has been explained on the basis of energy band, adsorbents, and defects [33, 34]. At a low electric field (regionÂ 1), FE might be mainly dependent on the surface states. With increasing electric field, the surface potential barrier decreases, and the current increases rapidly. At the high electric field (regionÂ 3), the field penetration breaks down the surface potential barrier to dominant the FE. Region 2 shows a competition between the surface states and the field penetration. The mechanism could be also explained by different field enhancement factors of emitters. The behavior of the emission current versus the applied voltage can be analyzed using the Fowlerâ€“Nordheim equation,

In addition, the emission stability of these three type nanostructures was also recorded by measuring the current fluctuation at an initial emission current intensity of
0.2
mA/cm 2
$0.2~\mbox{mA/cm}^{2}$ as shown in Fig.Â 6(c). For all the three samples, no obvious degradation of current density was observed during 240Â min. The emission current fluctuation for tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers was less than
Â± 10
${\pm}10$ Â %, which was more stable than the other two samples. Therefore, this good stability of FE demonstrates that as-fabricated tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers could be promising candidates in future FE device applications.

Section2.Heading: Photodegradation properties
Section2.Para:
Methylene blue (MB) was used to evaluate the photocatalytic abilities of the as-prepared samples. Figures 7(a)â€“(c) show the absorption spectra of MB solutions in the presence of cubic Cu2S, monoclinic Cu2S, and tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers, respectively. The intensity of the main absorption peaks of MB continued to decrease as irradiation proceeded. It is clear that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers have the best photocatalytic ability among the three samples; the photocatalytic ability of cubic Cu2S and monoclinic Cu2S nanoflowers were similar. This result is also consistent with the color change of these suspensions from blue to colorless (inset of Figs.Â 7(a)â€“(c)). The dependencies of the degradation efficiency on irradiation time of the samples are presented in Fig.Â 7(d). The degradation efficiency is defined as
C /
C 0
$C/C_{0}$ , where
C
$C$ and
C 0
${C}_{0}$ stand for the remnants and initial concentration of MB, respectively. According to the data, after irradiation for 60Â min, the remained MB is about 17Â % for tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers and about 28Â % for the other two samples. Comparing our two Cu2S nanocrystals with hexagonal Cu2S [35] and orthorhombic Cu2S [36] nanocrystals, we found that all of these Cu2S nanocrystals have similar photocatalytic properties. It indicates that the tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures have more significant photocatalytic performance.
Fig.Â 7
(a)â€“(c) Absorption spectra of MB solution obtained at room temperature in the presence of (a) cubic Cu2S nanoflowers, (b) monoclinic Cu2S nanoflowers, and (c) tetragonal Cu1.81S nanoflowers. (d)Â The extent of photodegradation of MB molecules as a function of irradiation time for these three types of samples

On the basis of the early research [37, 38], the photodegradation of MB in our work does not belong to decolorization but rather to decomposition. During the irradiation proceed, these three Cu x S samples are excited by visible light, electrons (
e âˆ’
$e^{-}$ ) were excited, and holes (
h +
$h^{+}$ ) were trapped by the hydroxyl groups (or
H 2
$\mathrm{H}_{2}$ O) at the catalyst surface to yield OHâ‹… radicals. Dissolved oxygen molecules (O2) react with the conduction band electrons (
e âˆ’
$e^{-}$ ) to yield superoxide radical anions (
O 2
â‹… âˆ’
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\cdot -}$ ), which react with water and generate the hydroperoxyl radicals (
HO 2 â‹…
$\mathrm{HO}_{2}^{\cdot}$ ) and then produce hydrogen peroxide and hydroxyl radicals (OHâ‹…), which can be written as follows [39]:
h +

OH â‹…
+
OH âˆ’
$$\begin{aligned} &{h}^{+} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O} \rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{OH}^{{\cdot}} \\ &{e}^{-} + \mathrm{O}_{{2}} \rightarrow \mathrm{O}_{2}^{\cdot -} \\ &\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\cdot -} + \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{HO}_{{2}}^{\cdot} \\ &\mathrm{HO}_{2}^{{\cdot}} + \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{O}_{2}^{\cdot -} \rightarrow \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2} + \mathrm{O}_{2} \\ & \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{2}+ e^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{OH}^{\cdot} + \mathrm{OH}^{-} \end{aligned} $$ The enhanced photocatalytic performance for tetragonal Cu1.81S nanostructures can be attributed to a little larger specific surface area and the defect of copper vacancies within the latticeÂ [40], which bring more hydroxyl radicals than other two samples. These hydroxyl radicals are known to be strong oxidizing agents and can degrade many organic pollutants to CO2, H2O, mineral salt, etc. To the best of our knowledge, the effect of defects had never been studied or proposed. The experimental observation indicates that the presence of defects in crystallographic structures has influence on the activity of photocatalyst and should be considered in future catalysis studies of Cu1.81S crystals. The exact function of defects is still under our research.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, marigold-like cubic Cu2S nanoflowers were successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal method. Cu2S (monoclinic) and Cu1.81S (tetragonal) nanoflowers were obtained subsequently via thermal annealing processes at different conditions. Field emission and photocatalytic properties of all the samples were measured and compared. It is demonstrated that the Cu1.81S (tetragonal) nanoflowers can notably improve the field emission and photocatalytic activities. Research shown here offers a promising candidate for future field emission display applications and high-efficiency sunlight photocatalysts.
